{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2986261,"name":"Yair Rimon","username":"yairrimon","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/y/dc4da7/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-07T23:09:03.628Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone!

This offseason our team has decided to develop two mechanisms in order to prepare and learn before the upcoming 2022 RAPID REACT season: a swerve drive and an elevator.

SWERVE:

WhatsApp Image 2022-01-08 at 00.29.55411×518 35 KB

WhatsApp Image 2022-01-08 at 00.30.08512×565 60.7 KB

At the end of last summer our team started prototyping our first swerve drive, or as we like to call it “In-Phase Steering”.

We wanted our swerve modules to implement KISS, and keep it “low fat” in terms of gearing and transmission design. By Integrating the absolute encoder into the spinning sub-module we managed to eliminate unnecessary gears and much complexity.

Another thing we tackled was working with a precise belt for changing the direction of the drive wheel. Worried about it not being stretched enough, too stretched and having a hard time getting it on we decided on making a simple spur gear system there for simplifying our swerve modules even more.

Reaching the end of the design process we were worried that the chassis frame and the wheels shaft brackets would be too brittle, so in order to optimize our weight to strength ratio we used Autodesk Inventor’s built in Shape Generator and mechanical analysis tools in order to achieve minimal weight and maximal strength for those critical parts.

We were glad to find out when driving into walls repeatedly and slamming the wheels on the ground there was no damage.

GrabCAD

Elevator:

Screenshot 2022-01-08 004555308×632 114 KB

Once we were done with the Swerve drive in October we thought it could use some company, so we designed and built a brand new elevator though a long lasting team tradition is to make arms. We really like arms.

The elevator is made out of a base, a stage and a carriage. The first stage is driven by a circular chain with turnbuckles in order to reduce the slip for the motor encoder, and the carriage is driven by a circular wire connected with a custom turnbuckle for max convenience when assembling while getting all the advantages of a chain and a wire driven elevator. The circular arrangement of the wire and chain gives us a 2-way cascading elevator which minimizes the chances of jams. For icing on the cake, 2 constant force springs on this elevator makes it as smooth as butter.

As with the swerve drive, considering most of the forces acting on the elevator in the design process was crucial for reaching peak efficiency

This time they wouldn’t let me slam it on the ground…

GrabCAD

WhatsApp Image 2022-01-08 at 00.25.50900×1600 222 KB

Have a great RAPID REACT season!

Questions are welcome, either on this thread or at cad@miscar1574.org.
